# Military history of New Zealand during World War I

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/1918_NZ_troops_at_French_port.jpg/330px-1918_NZ_troops_at_French_port.jpg)](/wiki/File:1918_NZ_troops_at_French_port.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:1918_NZ_troops_at_French_port.jpg "Enlarge")

New Zealand troops unloading at a French port in 1918.

The **military history of New Zealand during World War I** began in August
1914 when [Great Britain](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom") declared war
on [Germany](/wiki/German_Empire "German Empire") at the start of the [First
World War](/wiki/World_War_I "World War I"), the [New Zealand
government](/wiki/Government_of_New_Zealand "Government of New Zealand")
followed without hesitation, despite its geographic isolation and small
population. It was believed at the time that any declaration of war by the
United Kingdom automatically included [New Zealand](/wiki/New_Zealand "New
Zealand").

The total number of New Zealand troops and nurses to serve overseas in
1914–18, excluding those in British and other [Dominion](/wiki/Dominion
"Dominion") forces, was 100,444, from a population of just over a million.
Forty-two percent of men of military age served in the [New Zealand
Expeditionary Force](/wiki/New_Zealand_Expeditionary_Force "New Zealand
Expeditionary Force"), fighting in the [Gallipoli
Campaign](/wiki/Gallipoli_Campaign "Gallipoli Campaign") and on the [Western
Front](/wiki/Western_Front_\(World_War_I\) "Western Front \(World War I\)").
16,697 New Zealanders were [killed](/wiki/Killed_in_action "Killed in action")
and 41,317 were [wounded](/wiki/Wounded_in_action "Wounded in action") during
the war – a 58 percent [casualty rate](/wiki/Casualty_\(person\) "Casualty
\(person\)").[1] Approximately a further thousand men died within five years
of the war's end, as a result of injuries sustained, and 507 died while
training in New Zealand between 1914 and 1918.

The First World War saw [Māori](/wiki/M%C4%81ori_people "Māori people")
soldiers serve for the first time in a major conflict with the [New Zealand
Army](/wiki/New_Zealand_Army "New Zealand Army") (although a number had fought
in the [Second Boer War](/wiki/Second_Boer_War "Second Boer War") when New
Zealand recruiters chose to ignore British military policy of the time of
disallowing 'native' soldiers). A contingent took part in the [Gallipoli
Campaign](/wiki/Gallipoli_Campaign "Gallipoli Campaign"), and later served
with distinction on the Western Front as part of the [New Zealand (Māori)
Pioneer Battalion](/wiki/New_Zealand_\(M%C4%81ori\)_Pioneer_Battalion "New
Zealand \(Māori\) Pioneer Battalion"). 2688 [Māori](/wiki/M%C4%81ori_people
"Māori people") and 346 [Pacific islanders](/wiki/Pacific_Islander "Pacific
Islander"), including 150 [Niueans](/wiki/Niue "Niue"),[2] served with New
Zealand forces in total.

## Outbreak of the
war[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Military_history_of_New_Zealand_during_World_War_I&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Outbreak of the war")]

Upon the outbreak of the war, the [New Zealand
Government](/wiki/Reform_Government_of_New_Zealand "Reform Government of New
Zealand") authorised the raising of the [New Zealand Expeditionary
Force](/wiki/New_Zealand_Expeditionary_Force "New Zealand Expeditionary
Force") (NZEF) for service overseas. Mobilisation for the NZEF had already
begun, with preparations discreetly beginning a few days prior to the
declaration of war.[3]

##
Samoa[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Military_history_of_New_Zealand_during_World_War_I&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Samoa")]

Main article: [Occupation of German Samoa](/wiki/Occupation_of_German_Samoa
"Occupation of German Samoa")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/Occupation_of_German-
Samoa_1914.jpg/300px-Occupation_of_German-
Samoa_1914.jpg)](/wiki/File:Occupation_of_German-Samoa_1914.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Occupation_of_German-Samoa_1914.jpg "Enlarge")

The [Union Flag](/wiki/Union_Flag "Union Flag") being raised at the courthouse
at [Apia](/wiki/Apia "Apia") on 30 August 1914

The day after the declaration of war, the British Government requested New
Zealand seize the wireless station on the island of [Upolu](/wiki/Upolu
"Upolu"), part of [Imperial Germany](/wiki/Imperial_Germany "Imperial
Germany")'s protectorate of [German Samoa](/wiki/German_Samoa "German
Samoa"),[4] deeming it an "a great and urgent Imperial service."[5] A mixed
force of 1,413 men, known as the Samoan Expeditionary Force (SEF) under the
command of [Colonel](/wiki/Colonel "Colonel") [Robert
Logan](/wiki/Robert_Logan_\(politician\) "Robert Logan \(politician\)"), plus
six nursing sisters, sailed from New Zealand on 15 August 1914.[6] After
stopping in [Fiji](/wiki/Fiji "Fiji") to collect some guides and interpreters
as well as additional escort ships,[7] the New Zealanders arrived at
[Apia](/wiki/Apia "Apia") on 29 August 1914.[8]

Germany refused to officially surrender the islands but with only a minimal
military presence, there was little prospect for meaningful resistance. The
Governor of German Samoa, Dr. Erich Schultz, sent a message from the island's
radio station that no resistance would be offered. The New Zealanders
proceeded to land at Apia and seized key buildings and facilities without
interference. The only opposition encountered was at the radio station, where
the equipment was sabotaged by the German operators. Logan officially declared
German Samoa to be under the control of New Zealand the following day, 30
August 1914, in a ceremony at the courthouse in Apia.[9] When _Vizeadmiral_
([Vice Admiral](/wiki/Vice_Admiral "Vice Admiral")) [Maximilian von
Spee](/wiki/Maximilian_von_Spee "Maximilian von Spee"), commander of Germany's
East Asia Squadron, learned of the occupation, he hastened to Samoa with the
armoured cruisers [SMS _Scharnhorst_](/wiki/SMS_Scharnhorst "SMS Scharnhorst")
and [SMS _Gneisenau_](/wiki/SMS_Gneisenau "SMS Gneisenau"). Arriving at Apia
on 14 September 1914, the approach of the German ships was observed and the
New Zealanders prepared to defend themselves.[10] However, von Spee and his
ships soon departed for [Tahiti](/wiki/Tahiti "Tahiti"), with neither side
opening fire.[11] The SEF remained in Samoa until March 1915 at which time it
began returning to New Zealand, a process completed by the following
month.[12]

## Middle
East[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Military_history_of_New_Zealand_during_World_War_I&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Middle East")]

### Training in
Egypt[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Military_history_of_New_Zealand_during_World_War_I&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Training in Egypt")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Anzac_covering_force_landing_April_25_1915.jpg/200px-
Anzac_covering_force_landing_April_25_1915.jpg)](/wiki/File:Anzac_covering_force_landing_April_25_1915.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Anzac_covering_force_landing_April_25_1915.jpg "Enlarge")

Map of the landing at Anzac Cove on 25 April 1915

As early as October 1914 the main body of the NZEF sailed from
[Wellington](/wiki/Wellington "Wellington"). Diverted from their original
destination in Europe, the New Zealanders were landed in [Egypt](/wiki/Egypt
"Egypt"), where they helped repulse a [Turkish](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman
Empire") [attack on the Suez Canal](/wiki/Raid_on_the_Suez_Canal "Raid on the
Suez Canal") in February 1915.

The New Zealand volunteer soldiers remained encamped in Egypt, alongside their
Australian comrades, undergoing training prior to being sent to France.

### Gallipoli,
Turkey[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Military_history_of_New_Zealand_during_World_War_I&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Gallipoli, Turkey")]

On 25 April 1915, as part of the [New Zealand and Australian
Division](/wiki/New_Zealand_and_Australian_Division "New Zealand and
Australian Division"), the New Zealanders [landed at Anzac
Cove](/wiki/Landing_at_Anzac_Cove "Landing at Anzac Cove") on the
[Gallipoli](/wiki/Gallipoli "Gallipoli") peninsula, and fought in the
[Gallipoli Campaign](/wiki/Gallipoli_Campaign "Gallipoli Campaign") under the
command of British General [Alexander Godley](/wiki/Alexander_Godley
"Alexander Godley"). The combined British Empire and French operation was
mounted in order to eventually capture the Ottoman capital of
[Constantinople](/wiki/Constantinople "Constantinople") (now
[Istanbul](/wiki/Istanbul "Istanbul")). Because of a navigational error, the
Anzacs came ashore about a mile north of the intended landing point in their
initial landing. Instead of facing the expected beach and gentle slope they
found themselves at the bottom of steep cliffs, offering the few Turkish
defenders an ideal defensive position. Establishing a foothold, the Anzacs
found an advance to be impossible. On 30 April 1915, when the first news of
the landing reached New Zealand a half-day holiday was declared and impromptu
services were held – the origin of the commemorative public holiday, [ANZAC
Day](/wiki/ANZAC_Day "ANZAC Day"), recognised by New Zealand and Australia and
held each year on 25 April.[13][14]

### Evacuation from
Gallipoli[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Military_history_of_New_Zealand_during_World_War_I&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Evacuation from Gallipoli")]

Despite the blunder at [ANZAC Cove](/wiki/ANZAC_Cove "ANZAC Cove"), the New
Zealand soldiers fought valiantly throughout the campaign but it was a failed
venture overall. The estimated casualties on both sides were 392,000 of whom
131,000 were killed, with New Zealand casualties of 2,721 dead and 4,852
wounded. The [Allied forces](/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_I "Allies of World War
I") eventually evacuated in December 1915 and early January 1916. The
significance of the [Gallipoli Campaign](/wiki/Battle_of_Gallipoli "Battle of
Gallipoli") was strongly felt in New Zealand (and Australia) where it was the
first great conflict experienced by the fledgling nation. Before Gallipoli the
citizens of New Zealand were confident of the superiority of the [British
Empire](/wiki/British_Empire "British Empire") and were proud and eager to
offer their service. The campaign in Gallipoli shook that confidence.

The New Zealand Rifle Brigade (less two battalions) had meanwhile reached
Egypt in November 1915 and was sent into the Egyptian desert to help defeat a
[Senussi invasion](/wiki/Senussi_Campaign "Senussi Campaign") from Libya. The
1st Battalion fought two brisk but inexpensive actions south-west of
[Matruh](/wiki/Mersa_Matruh "Mersa Matruh") as part of a mixed force
(including British, Australians, and Indians), one on Christmas Day, the other
on 23 January 1916. Both were successful and broke the back of the invasion.
In mid-February the 1st Battalion rejoined the rest of the brigade at Moascar
in the Suez Canal area.

### Palestine
Campaign[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Military_history_of_New_Zealand_during_World_War_I&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Palestine Campaign")]

In [Egypt](/wiki/Egypt "Egypt"), the New Zealand Expeditionary Force was
reorganised into the New Zealand Mounted Brigade and the [New Zealand
Division](/wiki/New_Zealand_Division "New Zealand Division") (infantry).
Reinforcements from New Zealand replaced the Australian component of the
division, which embarked for France in April 1916. The New Zealand Mounted
Brigade, 147 officers and 2,897 other ranks, remained in Egypt as part of the
[Anzac Mounted Division](/wiki/Anzac_Mounted_Division "Anzac Mounted
Division"). In April 1916, it was deployed to the [Sinai
Peninsula](/wiki/Sinai_Peninsula "Sinai Peninsula") where it took part in the
ultimately successful [Sinai and Palestine
Campaign](/wiki/Sinai_and_Palestine_Campaign "Sinai and Palestine Campaign")
against the [Turks](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman Empire"). New Zealanders
fought in most of the battles leading up to the fall of Jerusalem and the
defeat of the Ottoman Army, and were praised for their fighting alongside
their Australian and British comrades. In 1919, Field Marshal [Sir Edmund
Allenby](/wiki/Edmund_Allenby,_1st_Viscount_Allenby "Edmund Allenby, 1st
Viscount Allenby"), said this of the New Zealand soldiers in the Sinai
campaign;

    

    

    

    

    

    "Nothing daunted these intrepid fighters: to them nothing was impossible."

A total of 17,723 New Zealanders served in this campaign and New Zealand
casualties were 640 killed in action and 1,146 wounded.

## Training in
England[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Military_history_of_New_Zealand_during_World_War_I&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Training in England")]

While in England – either freshly arrived from New Zealand or having already
served at [Gallipoli](/wiki/Gallipoli "Gallipoli") and awaiting transfer to
the Western Front – New Zealand troops were stationed at [Sling
Camp](/wiki/Sling_Camp "Sling Camp"), an annexe of [Bulford
Camp](/wiki/Bulford_Camp "Bulford Camp") in [Wiltshire](/wiki/Wiltshire
"Wiltshire"). The troops who were still stationed at the camp at the end of
the war created the giant chalk kiwi known as the [Bulford
Kiwi](/wiki/Bulford_Kiwi "Bulford Kiwi") whilst waiting to be repatriated.

## Western
Front[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Military_history_of_New_Zealand_during_World_War_I&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Western Front")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/New_Zealand_trench_Flers_September_1916.jpg/250px-
New_Zealand_trench_Flers_September_1916.jpg)](/wiki/File:New_Zealand_trench_Flers_September_1916.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:New_Zealand_trench_Flers_September_1916.jpg "Enlarge")

Infantry from the 2nd Battalion, Auckland Regiment, New Zealand Division in
the Switch Line near Flers, taken some time in September 1916, after the
[Battle of Flers-Courcelette](/wiki/Battle_of_Flers-Courcelette "Battle of
Flers-Courcelette")

In France, the New Zealand Division settled in on the stalemated [Western
Front](/wiki/Western_Front_\(World_War_I\) "Western Front \(World War I\)")
and their first major trial was during the Battle of the Somme. It took part
in the Fourth Army's attack on 15 September, under the command of the [British
XV Corps](/wiki/XV_Corps_\(United_Kingdom\) "XV Corps \(United Kingdom\)"). By
the time they were relieved on 4 October, the New Zealanders had advanced
three kilometres and captured eight kilometres of enemy front line. 7,048 had
become casualties, of whom 1,560 were killed.

In June 1917, the New Zealand Division further distinguished itself in the
[storming of Messines Ridge](/wiki/Battle_of_Messines_\(1917\) "Battle of
Messines \(1917\)") and the capture of the village of [Messines](/wiki/Mesen
"Mesen"). On 7 June, after the detonation of nearly 500 tons of explosives in
huge mines on both sides of the New Zealand sector, the 2nd and 3rd Brigades
scrambled over the top, in and out of shell holes, and up the battered slopes.
Carrying the German front line and supports, they were soon into the ruined
village. The 1st Brigade passed through, helped on the left by a solitary
tank, to the final objective. With prisoners and booty including many guns it
was a striking success at no great cost; but the German artillery revived and
by the time the division was relieved on 9 and 10 June it had lost 3,700 men,
evenly distributed between the three brigades.

The New Zealand Division's next major engagement was at
[Passchendaele](/wiki/Battle_of_Passchendaele "Battle of Passchendaele") in
October 1917. The division had been training since the end of August to
overcome the numerous concrete pillboxes in this sector. The first objective
was the Gravenstafel Spur, attacked before dawn on 4 October, as part of a
major advance. The 1st and 4th Brigades forestalled a heavy German counter-
attack, and the supporting artillery barrage inflicted frightful slaughter on
the waiting Germans. Crossing this scene of carnage, the 1st and 4th Brigades
gained their objectives after a hard fight, inflicting exceptionally heavy
loss on the enemy and capturing much equipment. For such a resounding success
the 1,700 New Zealand casualties, though a sad loss, did not in current terms
seem excessive. But heavy rain turned the countryside into a bog and tragedy
lay ahead.

A British attack on the ninth on Bellevue Spur and part of the main
Passchendaele ridge gained a little ground at prohibitive cost. Heavy swathes
of barbed wire still girdled the hillside, however, and belated and meagre
heavy artillery made no impression on them, nor on the many pillboxes beyond.
New Zealand gunners slaved to breaking point to get only a few guns and
howitzers forward, but stable platforms and accurate fire were unattainable.

The division returned to the attack on 12 October, with the 2nd and 3rd
Brigades. There was little to encourage the men as they waited overnight in a
morass under steady rain. Shelled in their assembly area, some were shelled
again by their own guns when the thin barrage opened at 5.25 a.m., and then
they led off into a deluge of small-arms fire, speckled with geyser-like
eruptions as shells exploded in the mud. Worst of all was the wire, covered
with deadly fire, its few gaps deliberate deathtraps. Some men tried to crawl
under it, some threw themselves at it, two got right through and were killed
in the act of hurling grenades at the loopholes of the nearest pillbox. The
left gained 500 yards of slippery slope, the centre 200 heartbreaking yards,
the right nothing until the 80-odd occupants of two blockhouses and a trench
used up all their ammunition. Then they were captured, blockhouses and all, by
two brave and skillful men, sole survivors of two Otago platoons.

For these small gains, the New Zealanders suffered 640 dead and 2,100 wounded.
For the first time the division had failed in a major operation. After this
failure, the division continued to hold a sector of the line. The steady drain
of men while units only held the line was less spectacular, though it made up
half the losses of the division. Here, before withdrawing from the front, 400
more men were lost in the 4th Brigade alone.

The division now had four brigades, making it one of the largest on the
Western Front, and was stationed in the [Polygon
Wood](/wiki/Polygon_Wood,_Zonnebeke "Polygon Wood, Zonnebeke") area. An attack
by the 2nd Brigade on 3 December 1917 gained useful ground but failed to
capture Polderhoek Chateau. When the division was relieved, on 24 February
1918, three "quiet" months had cost 3,000 men, more than 1,873 of them killed.

As the Germans launched their great [Spring Offensive](/wiki/Spring_Offensive
"Spring Offensive") of 1918, the New Zealand Division was rushed to stem a
breakthrough in the [First Battle of the
Somme](/wiki/First_Battle_of_the_Somme_\(1918\) "First Battle of the Somme
\(1918\)"), which threatened [Amiens](/wiki/Amiens "Amiens"). The gap was
between the British [IV](/wiki/IV_Corps_\(United_Kingdom\) "IV Corps \(United
Kingdom\)") and [V Corps](/wiki/V_Corps_\(United_Kingdom\) "V Corps \(United
Kingdom\)") in the Ancre Valley. After confused fighting, the New Zealanders
eventually gained the upper hand and soon were counter-attacking advantageous
land, stabilising the British line. Later in the year, they excelled in the
open country fighting that was brought about by the Allied counter-offensive.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Advance-to-
victory-1918-1000.jpg/220px-Advance-to-
victory-1918-1000.jpg)](/wiki/File:Advance-to-victory-1918-1000.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Advance-to-victory-1918-1000.jpg "Enlarge")

The advance of the New Zealand Division – part of the Third Army’s IV Corps –
during the 100 Days Offensive.

In their last action of the war, the division
[captured](/wiki/Capture_of_Le_Quesnoy_\(1918\) "Capture of Le Quesnoy
\(1918\)") the ancient fortress ([Vauban](/wiki/Vauban "Vauban")-designed)
town of [Le Quesnoy](/wiki/Le_Quesnoy "Le Quesnoy") in a daring assault on 4
November 1918. The day proved to be the division's most successful of their
whole time on the Western Front as they pushed east and advanced ten
kilometres, capturing 2,000 German soldiers and 60 field guns. The town
occupied a strategic position in north-eastern France and had been held by the
Germans since 1914. Although with no specific orders indicating that the town
need to be captured with any haste, the New Zealand soldiers were determined
to and just before midday the first New Zealand troops reached the outer walls
and scaled them with ladders. Propping the ladders against the precariously
narrow inner walls, sections of one New Zealand battalion ascended the walls
and engaged in hand-to-hand fighting with fleeing German defenders. The few
thousand strong German garrison surrendered soon after New Zealand soldiers
entered the town itself.

The infantry were relieved on the eastern side of the forest at midnight on
5–6 November and the war ended five days later. The division left the Third
Army on 28 November, and marched through Belgium, to entrain at the German
frontier for Cologne and take up billets in neighbouring towns as part of the
army of occupation. Demobilisation soon started and at Mülheim near Cologne
the division was finally disbanded on 25 March 1919.

The cost of maintaining the division for two and a half years on the Western
Front was appalling. Altogether some 13,250 New Zealanders died of wounds or
sickness as a direct result of this campaign, including 50 as prisoners of war
and more than 700 at home. Another 35,000 were wounded, and 414 prisoners of
war were ultimately repatriated. The total casualties therefrom approached
50,000, well over half the number of those who served in France or Belgium.

## Other
theatres[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Military_history_of_New_Zealand_during_World_War_I&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Other theatres")]

New Zealand also contributed to the war at sea. The [New Zealand Naval
Forces](/wiki/New_Zealand_Naval_Forces "New Zealand Naval Forces") was a
Division of the [Royal Navy](/wiki/Royal_Navy "Royal Navy"). Immediately after
the start of the war, the cruiser [HMS _Philomel_](/wiki/HMS_Philomel_\(1890\)
"HMS Philomel \(1890\)"), loaned to New Zealand as a training ship, was
augmented with 70 New Zealand reservists and sailed with two [Royal
Navy](/wiki/Royal_Navy "Royal Navy") cruisers to escort the New Zealand troops
sent to occupy German Samoa. Later in 1914 these three ships also escorted the
New Zealand Expeditionary Force to Egypt.

From January 1915, _Philomel_ patrolled the [Gulf of
Alexandretta](/wiki/Gulf_of_Alexandretta "Gulf of Alexandretta") in the
Eastern Mediterranean, supporting several landings and sustaining three fatal
casualties, one being the first New Zealander killed in action in the war. She
also took part in the defence of the [Suez Canal](/wiki/Suez_Canal "Suez
Canal"), operations in the [Gulf of Aden](/wiki/Gulf_of_Aden "Gulf of Aden")
and patrols in the [Persian Gulf](/wiki/Persian_Gulf "Persian Gulf"). Although
refitting from time to time at [Malta](/wiki/Malta "Malta") or
[Bombay](/wiki/Bombay "Bombay") kept her seaworthy, age eventually forced her
out of the war and in March 1917 she returned to Wellington for a major
overhaul.

New Zealand was not subject to any significant direct military threat during
the war. Although Germany had plans for naval raids on Australia and New
Zealand, the threat from her Asiatic Squadron did not eventuate, as that force
moved across the Pacific before being destroyed at the [Battle of the Falkland
Islands](/wiki/Battle_of_the_Falkland_Islands "Battle of the Falkland
Islands").

In June 1917, a German surface raider, the [SMS
_Wolf_](/wiki/SMS_Wolf_\(auxiliary_cruiser\) "SMS Wolf \(auxiliary cruiser\)")
entered New Zealand waters. She laid two small minefields in New Zealand
waters and sank two merchant ships. One (the _Port Kembla_) off [Farewell
Spit](/wiki/Farewell_Spit "Farewell Spit"), and another (the _Wairuna_) off
the [Kermadec Islands](/wiki/Kermadec_Islands "Kermadec Islands"). Two fishing
trawlers, the [_Nora Niven_](/wiki/Jas_J_Niven_%26_Co "Jas J Niven & Co") and
_Simplon_ , were fitted as minesweepers and took up sweeping duties in these
areas. Another brief flurry of activity occurred when [Felix von
Luckner](/wiki/Felix_von_Luckner "Felix von Luckner"), imprisoned on Motuihe
Island after being captured in the [Society Islands](/wiki/Society_Islands
"Society Islands"), escaped and commandeered a small vessel before being
recaptured in the Kermadec Islands.

New Zealand also contributed a wireless troop to the [Mesopotamian
Campaign](/wiki/Mesopotamian_Campaign "Mesopotamian Campaign"). The Wireless
Troop was formed in New Zealand and arrived at Basra in April 1916. In
Mesopotamia the New Zealand troop was amalgamated with the [1st Australian
Wireless Signal Squadron](/wiki/1st_Australian_Wireless_Signal_Squadron "1st
Australian Wireless Signal Squadron"), forming "C" Wireless Troop of the Anzac
Squadron. The troop was much affected by disease, but once in operation was
attached to the Cavalry Division in the assault on Baghdad. The Wireless Troop
was among the first batch of troops to enter the city on 11 March 1917. The
Wireless Troop joined further operations in Mesopotamia and was then moved to
Persia. In June 1917, the troop was redirected to France, where it was
absorbed into the New Zealand Divisional Signal Company.

New Zealand had no air force of her own during the First World War but several
hundred New Zealanders served with the [Royal Flying
Corps](/wiki/Royal_Flying_Corps "Royal Flying Corps"), the [Royal Naval Air
Service](/wiki/Royal_Naval_Air_Service "Royal Naval Air Service") and the
[Royal Air Force](/wiki/Royal_Air_Force "Royal Air Force").

## Recruiting and
Conscription[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Military_history_of_New_Zealand_during_World_War_I&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Recruiting and Conscription")]

When the supply of volunteers for reinforcements for the New Zealand
Expeditionary Force slowed, conscription was introduced, with the first ballot
held in Wellington on 16 November 1916.[15] Men between 20 and 45 could be
conscripted, subject to a medical check and limited rights of objection on
conscience, family or business grounds.

Conscription was extended to Māori for the "Native Contingent" in late 1917,
with the first "Māori ballot" for the Waikato district held in May 1918.[16]
There wes resistance in the Waikato (led by [Princess Te
Puea](/wiki/Princess_Te_Puea "Princess Te Puea")) to conscription. By the end
of the war 552 Māori had been balloted, but no Māori conscripts had been sent
overseas. And 2,227 Māori served in the war; about 4.5% of the Māori
population or under half of the total contribution per head of the total New
Zealand population. [17]

##
Hospitals[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Military_history_of_New_Zealand_during_World_War_I&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Hospitals")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/1917_Oct_p273_Railway_Magazine_Walton-
on-Thames.jpg/220px-1917_Oct_p273_Railway_Magazine_Walton-on-
Thames.jpg)](/wiki/File:1917_Oct_p273_Railway_Magazine_Walton-on-Thames.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:1917_Oct_p273_Railway_Magazine_Walton-on-Thames.jpg "Enlarge")

Walton-on-Thames railway station was about one and a quarter miles from No 2
New Zealand General Hospital

New Zealand Hospitals were set up at [Port Said](/wiki/Port_Said "Port Said")
and [Suez](/wiki/Suez "Suez") in 1915,[18] [Walton-on-Thames](/wiki/Walton-on-
Thames#History "Walton-on-Thames") in 1915,[19] and [Amiens](/wiki/Amiens
"Amiens"), [Brockenhurst](/wiki/Brockenhurst#History "Brockenhurst"),
[Codford](/wiki/Codford#Military_camps "Codford") and
[Hornchurch](/wiki/Grey_Towers#First_World_War "Grey Towers") in 1916.
Hospital ships [Maheno](/wiki/SS_Maheno#World_War_I "SS Maheno")[18] and
[Marama](/wiki/SS_Marama "SS Marama")[20][21] were converted in 1915.[18]
Walton closed in 1919.[22]

##
Repatriation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Military_history_of_New_Zealand_during_World_War_I&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Repatriation")]

Shortages of shipping, influenza[23] and strikes[24] were among causes[25] for
delays in repatriating troops after the war. The frustration of the delay
resulted in riots at [Sling Camp](/wiki/Sling_Camp "Sling Camp") in March
1919[24] and at [Ismailia](/wiki/Ismailia "Ismailia") in July. Allied
governments paid compensation for looted Egyptian shops.[23] New Zealand's
share of the cost was £2,529[26] (2016 equivalent $250,000).[27]

## Cemeteries and
Memorials[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Military_history_of_New_Zealand_during_World_War_I&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Cemeteries and Memorials")]

New Zealand war deaths are buried or commemorated in CWGC ([Commonwealth War
Graves Commission](/wiki/Commonwealth_War_Graves_Commission "Commonwealth War
Graves Commission")) cemeteries with other allied soldiers. Gallipoli dead are
buried in 24 CWGC cemeteries in Turkey, and in CWGC cemeteries in Egypt,
Gibraltar, Greece and Malta. There are memorials to the New Zealand missing on
[Chunuk Bair](/wiki/Chunuk_Bair "Chunuk Bair") and at three CWGC cemeteries:
[Hill 60 Cemetery](/wiki/Hill_60_Cemetery "Hill 60 Cemetery"), [Lone Pine
Cemetery](/wiki/Lone_Pine_Cemetery "Lone Pine Cemetery") and [Twelve Tree
Copse Cemetery](/wiki/Twelve_Tree_Copse_Cemetery "Twelve Tree Copse
Cemetery").[28]

On the Western Front missing New Zealand soldiers are commemorated in
cemeteries near where they were lost rather than at the large memorials of
[Menin Gate](/wiki/Menin_Gate "Menin Gate") and the [Thiepval
Memorial](/wiki/Thiepval_Memorial "Thiepval Memorial") on the Somme. The New
Zealand monuments to the missing are at Messines in Belgium and Armentierses,
Longueval ([Caterpillar Valley Cemetery](/wiki/Caterpillar_Valley_Cemetery
"Caterpillar Valley Cemetery")), Grevillers, and Marfaux in France. There are
four national battlefield memorials at Passchendaele, Messines, the Somme and
Le Quesnoy.[29]
